newsitem.title: UK: UK Feb-Apr primary fuel use drops 9.7 pct yr/yr.
newsitem.headline: UK Feb-Apr primary fuel use drops 9.7 pct yr/yr.

text.p: Britain's primary fuel consumption from February to April this year was 9.7 percent lower than the same period in 1996, preliminary Department of Trade and Industry figures showed on Tuesday.
Total consumption equalled 59 million tonnes of oil equivalent.
Coal consumption fell by 20.8 percent because of a 29 percent drop in coal usage at power stations, statistics showed.
Natural gas use fell by 11.6 percent in the three month period, while petroleum consumption dropped 5.6 percent, according to the DTI.
Primary electricity consumption, which includes nuclear, hydro and imported electricity, grew by 9.6 percent.
The largest part of the drop in petroleum consumption came from the non-energy sector, which experienced a 13.2 percent fall.
Deliveries to the petro-chemical industry were down 14.5 percent and petroleum coke shipments to the industrial sector sank by 30 percent.
